Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Relative perception: from organisms to cells to molecules

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Integrating mathematical approaches into biology will produce a fundamentally new way of understanding biology from a quantitative perspective. This proposal is focused on Weber's Law as a unifying framework to study signaling and decision making at multiple scales of biological organization. This emerging design principle in biology uncovers similarities across biological scales, about how organisms, cells, and potentially molecules that form the cells sense their respective surroundings. Educating the next generation of interdisciplinary students will require integrating quantitative skills into biology teaching early on. The project emphasize the integration of research and education in order to train the next generation of scientists across several levels of education, from middle- and high-school students to undergraduate and graduate students. The undergraduate and graduate students will present their work at conferences, and they will have opportunities to author publications on their research. In addition, a Systems Biology course module developed as a result of the proposed research and teaching efforts will be disseminated through the web to nearby public school districts and community colleges.

The research will pursue the framework of Weber's Law as a design principle across biological hierarchies. Understanding cellular sensitivity to a signaling cue is a fundamental question in biology. Weber's Law describes the ability of our sensory systems to scale sensitivity logarithmically to background, mediating their dynamic range. The PI's research has uncovered evidence that Weber's Law may also govern cellular and molecular systems. The concept of Weber's Law has the potential to lead to discovery of new biological mechanisms, challenge the present paradigm of how cells signal, and raise new questions on the evolution of biological sensory mechanisms. The research will employ mathematical modeling, microscopy, and genomic engineering in order to understand how diverse biological systems maintain sensitivity to external perturbations across a large dynamic range of stimuli.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: Relative perception: from organisms to cells to molecules

We perceive our world in a relative manner. Five minutes matter a great deal when we are running late for a meeting, but are insignificant in the span of years. This relative sensing allows our sensory systems to work across a wide range of conditions. The research in this NSF project built on the discovery that each cell in our body also senses signal in a relative manner.  Sensing signal in a relative manner means that a cell must have a way to remember the past level of signal and computes the ratio between that past level and the present level of signal. How does a cell encode such a sophisticated computation -- having memory and computing ratio?  Tackling this kind of questions required combining mathematical modeling and experiments. Employing interdisciplinary approaches, findings from this project demonstrated how relative sensing in cells can be implemented in many protein networks that behave like linear transmitters as well as in a common class of proteins that behave like logarithmic sensors. Findings from the project also demonstrated how by sensing signal in a relative way, the cell can extract much more information from the environment. These findings contribute insights for how cells communicate with one another in our body to coordinate day-to-day functions.

Tackling problems in biological research increasingly requires integrating mathematics into traditional experiments. The broader impact activities in this NSF project focused on training the next generation of biology students to combine mathematics with biology. Researchers in the project developed a new, interdisciplinary course that teaches systems approaches to undergraduate students. Researchers in the project also worked closely with the Center for Teaching, Learning, and Outreach at California Institute of Technology to host high school students and teachers to do summer research in the lab.  As a result of the program, new science modules were implemented in the STEAM Academy at Burke, in the El Rancho Unified School District, CA. The trained high school students have gone on to pursue science majors in college. Finally, the project supported a number of graduate students who have continued to pursue research career in STEM.
